titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the W. J. Linton Collection
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 04:07

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of the papers of author and wood engraver W. J. Linton, including personal and professional correspondence, writings by and about Linton, drawings and prints, personal papers, and other papers covering Linton's life and work in England and the United States. The papers are primarily those inherited by his daughters Ellen Wade Linton and Margaret Linton Mather, with additions from family friends.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired chiefly through gifts of Margaret Linton Mather, 1911-1929, and Ellen Wade Linton, 1918. Additional gifts from William Fowler Hopson and Ada M. Hopson, 1918-1920; Alfred E. Hamill (Yale 1905), 1928-1929; and Howard Mansfield (Yale 1871, MA Hon 1891), 1929. Other acquistions are noted at the folder level in the finding aid. For additional information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Correspondence, 1829-1931. II. Writings by Linton, 1845-1898. III. Writings about Linton, 1839-1937. IV. Graphic Material, 1838-1913. V. Personal Papers, 1838-1902. VI. Other Papers, 1797-1922.

bioghist.head: W. J. Linton (1812-1897)
bioghist.p: The British wood engraver, author, historian, printer, publisher, and political activist William James Linton was born in London on December 7, 1812. He immigrated to New York in 1866 and in 1867 settled at Appledore, a small farm and cottage in Hamden, Connecticut, just north of New Haven. There he founded his Appledore Private Press and wrote and printed several of his most notable works including The Masters of Wood-Engraving (1886). Linton died in New Haven, at the home of his daughter Margaret Linton Mather, on December 29, 1897.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: W. J. Linton Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained.
This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call numbers: MS Vault Shelves Linton, Uncat MS Vault File, Uncat MSS 600, Uncat MSS 878.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Grace Linton Cook Papers About W. J. Linton (GEN MSS 1406), Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The W. J. Linton Collection chiefly contains William James Linton's papers, including correspondence, autograph manuscripts and other writings by and about Linton, graphic work, and personal papers, which were inherited by his daughters Ellen Wade Linton and Margaret Linton Mather, when their father died in New Haven, Connecticut, in 1897. It includes literary and graphic material that Linton brought with him when he emigrated from England to the United States in the mid-1860s, as well as work he accomplished while living in Connecticut. Once the papers entered the Yale University Library beginning in 1911, they were added through 1929 by family members and by gifts from three local admirers of Linton who were also friends of the family: the engraver William Fowler Hopson and two Yale graduates, Howard Mansfield and Alfred E. Hamill. These substantial gifts combine to comprise the largest group of Linton's autograph literary manuscripts, examples of engravings and other printed work he created both in England and the United States, and material related to Linton's classic works The History of Wood Engraving in America (1882) and Masters of Wood Engraving (1886).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The W. J. Linton Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legalheirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

Wood-engravers -- Great Britain

controlaccess.corpname: Central Committee of the Friends of Poland

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Letters to Linton, Letters from Linton, and Third-party Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains single letters from friends and colleagues and many of whom are engravers or family members of engravers writing in reply to Linton's inquiries about the profession and history of wood engraving, as well as from others, such as the artist William Page who wrote to praise Linton for his fine work in reproducing one of his paintings. Another prominent group of correspondents are those asking for permission to use Linton's poems in anthologies, while two poets, Walter Savage Landor and Richard Henry Stoddard, wrote to send poems they had written about Linton. High-profile correspondents include Ralph Waldo Emerson (writing about an oil portrait of himself by David Scott that Linton was engraving), William Morris, John Ruskin (writing about Brantwood, Linton's home that Ruskin acquired when Linton moved to the United States), and Walt Whitman. Several of the letters in the series are related to Linton's work with Guiseppe Mazzini and the Central Committee of the Friends of Poland. The subseries Letters from Linton holds an interesting set of letters to H. W. Thompson giving him instructions for the dispersal and disposal of papers Linton had left behind in England. The subseries Third-party Correspondence holds a small group of letters that others, including family members, wrote or received about Linton and his work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a mix of bound volumes compiled by Linton, autograph manuscripts (many of which were written on the versos of stacks of Universal Republican Alliance subscription coupons), and printed items including tear sheets with published essays and poems.
All works are autograph manuscripts, some with corrections, unless otherwise noted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series two is organized into six subseries: Bound Compilations, Essays, Lectures, Poems, Prospectuses, and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A group of bound thematic compilations created by Linton. Many of the writings appear to have come from The English Republic , edited by Linton and published in London 1851-1855. Titles are taken from their hand-lettered spines.

did.unittitle: "Essays and Reviews from The English Republic "
"Ket's Rebellion" ("The Rebellion of Ket the Tanner")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five chapters as they originally appeared in The English Republic 3 (1854), collected to form a continuous narrative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most published in the Irish Nation in the 1840s.

"Part 1: Moral and Religious" and "Part 2: Religious and Political"
"Prose and Verse by W. J. Linton, a supplement to 1886"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Compilation of essays, poems, and letters to editors clipped from publications, with small Appledore Press folders and pamphlets, mounted on blank pages; printed title page and table of contents.

did.unittitle: "Articles written on W. J. Linton and others"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Not related to the above volumes. Contains articles by Linton on James Watson, Joseph Mazzini, European Republicans, Chartists, and engraving, and about Linton by Frederick G. Kitton and Burton J. Hendrick, clipped from publications; also one on John Ruskin by Anne Thackeray Ritchie, which features a section on Brantwood. The volume was owned by Ellen Wade Linton (1852-1938). Laid in: postcard from Ellen Linton to Ada M. Hopson (1916).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Additional essays appear in "Other Writings," including essay-length letters to editors printed in publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript set up as printer's dummy indicating the placement of engravings by Linton to illustrate the volume. The preface, captions, contents, and notes written in ink and pencil, with the illustrations shown by sketches in pencil or mounted prints; laid between original boards. Accompanied by one of the first impressions of the engraved title page of the 1882 edition (Hamden: Appledore Private Press, 1882).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into four subseries: Drawings and Paintings, Prints, Serials, and Sketchbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds graphic work created by Linton in several media, including three small oil portraits of family members. Important here are albums of his engraved work from the early 1840s, 1850s, and 1860s, including an album compiled by Lancelot Wade Linton (ca. 1846-1863), one of Linton's three sons. Also present are four of his English sketchbooks with graphite and watercolor views of the Lake District.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four drawings in graphite and watercolor on paper: apple tree, house exterior, study, and press room; the latter drawing inscribed: "Original drawing done for S. P. Avery."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Removed from Linton's Golden Apples of Hesperus (BEIN 2005 1169).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph journal of travels in the Lake District of Westmorland, May 18, 1862 to 1863. Descriptions in verse or prose, illustrated with sketches in graphite and watercolor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sketches and drawings in graphite and watercolor made in the Lake District between May and July 1863.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sketches and drawings in graphite and watercolor made in the Lake District between July and August 1863, and December 1864.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds a small group of Linton's personal papers, including autobiographical entries from contemporary publications, a passport and calling card, his membership certificate from the National Academy of Design, and photographs of his home and grave in Hamden, Connecticut. Important in the series are the earliest minutes of the Walthamstow Working Men's Association in suburban London, for which Linton was secretary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraved card for "W. J. Linton. Portrait Painter, 13 Upper Berkeley Street West."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clippings with writings in English, French, and Italian by and about Mazzini, accompanied by a manuscript note in French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An agreement between Linton and Richard Henry Stoddard and the Scribner's firm, for preparing and publishing a collection of English verse. Hectograph copy with autograph signatures.

did.unittitle: Mailing wrapper, Adams Express from McClurg Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous groups of pages, their relationship to Linton is unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds a diverse collection of material related to W. J. Linton, his family members, and his colleagues. Important here is a set of graphite drawings of zoo animals by Walter Crane, made while he was serving an apprenticeship with Linton. Also present are graphic works by other artists, including James Gillray, that arrived with the Linton papers.

did.unittitle: Linton, Ellen Wade, "W. J. Linton calendars"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript monthly calendars featuring quotes from Linton's writings, issued as Christmas tokens for family members.
Another set of calendars (with variant verses) is in the Grace Linton Cook Papers about W. J. Linton (GEN MSS 1406).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handmade booklet for Emily Wade Linton, with watercolor drawings; laid in: sketches of feathers and sea shells.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript booklet with four chapters on the world geography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With autograph notes on his trip to England and notes of about Linton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript notes in unidentified hands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sketched in the Zoological Gardens, Regents Park, London, between 1858 and 1862, while Crane was apprenticed to Linton.
